text.3_Daf, 0_Halakhah: to her, and opened her womb.1 The Key of the Revival of the Dead, for it is written, And ye shall
text.3_Daf, 1_Halakhah: know that I am the Lord, when I have opened your graves.2 In Palestine they said: Also the Key of
text.3_Daf, 2_Halakhah: Sustenance, for it is said, Thou openest thy hand etc.3 Why does not R. Johanan include also this
text.3_Daf, 3_Halakhah: [key]? — Because in his view sustenance is [included in] Rain.4
text.3_Daf, 4_Halakhah: R. ELIEZER SAYS: ON THE FIRST DAY OF THE FEAST etc. The question was asked,
text.3_Daf, 5_Halakhah: Whence did R. Eliezer derive this? Did he learn it from Lulab5 or from the Libation of Water?6 If he
text.3_Daf, 6_Halakhah: learnt it from Lulab, then just as the obligation of the use of the Lulab comes into force on the [first]
text.3_Daf, 7_Halakhah: day of Tabernacles, so too should we begin to make mention of rain on that day. Or perhaps he learnt
text.3_Daf, 8_Halakhah: it from Libation. [If so, then] just as Water Libation may be [carried out] on the evening [preceding
text.3_Daf, 9_Halakhah: the first day] — (for a Master [interpreting the verse], And the meal-offering thereof and their
text.3_Daf, 10_Halakhah: drink-offerings,7 said, Even by night)-so too should one begin to make mention of rain on that
text.3_Daf, 11_Halakhah: evening!8 — Come and hear: R. Abbahu said: R. Eliezer deduced it from Lulab only. Some there are
text.3_Daf, 12_Halakhah: who say: R. Abbahu had a tradition. Whilst others say: He based it on a Baraitha. Which is the
text.3_Daf, 13_Halakhah: Baraitha? — It has been taught: ‘When do we [begin to] make mention of Rain? R. Eliezer says:
text.3_Daf, 14_Halakhah: From the time of the taking up of the Lulab; R. Joshua says, From the time when the Lulab is
text.3_Daf, 15_Halakhah: discarded.9 Said R. Eliezer: Seeing that these Four Species are intended only to make intercession
text.3_Daf, 16_Halakhah: for water,10 therefore as these cannot [grow] without water so the world [too] cannot exist without
text.3_Daf, 17_Halakhah: water. R. Joshua said to him: Is not rain on the Feast a sure sign of [God's] anger? R. Eliezer replied:
text.3_Daf, 18_Halakhah: I too did not say to pray but to make mention. And just as one makes mention of the Revival of the
text.3_Daf, 19_Halakhah: Dead all the year round11 although it will take place only in its proper time, so too should mention be
text.3_Daf, 20_Halakhah: made of the Power of Rain all the year round although it comes only in its due season. Therefore if
text.3_Daf, 21_Halakhah: one desires to make mention all the year round he may do so. Rabbi says: I hold the view that when
text.3_Daf, 22_Halakhah: one ceases to pray [for rain]12 one should also no longer make mention of it. R. Judah b. Bathyra
text.3_Daf, 23_Halakhah: says: On the second day of the Feast one [begins] to make mention. R. Akiba says: On the sixth day
text.3_Daf, 24_Halakhah: of the Feast. R. Judah says in the name of R. Joshua: The last to step before the Ark on the last day
text.3_Daf, 25_Halakhah: of the Feast makes mention, the first does not; on the first day of Passover the first makes mention,
text.3_Daf, 26_Halakhah: the last does not. Did not then R. Eliezer reply well to R. Joshua?- R. Joshua can answer you: It is
text.3_Daf, 27_Halakhah: quite in order to make mention of the Revival of the Dead [all the year round], since any day may be
text.3_Daf, 28_Halakhah: its time, but is rain seasonable at all times? Have we not learnt: Should Nisan terminate and then rain
text.3_Daf, 29_Halakhah: fall it is a sign of [God's] anger, for it is said, Is it not wheat harvest to-day etc.?13
text.3_Daf, 30_Halakhah: ‘R. Judah b. Bathyra says: on the second day of the Feast one [begins] to make mention’. What is
text.3_Daf, 31_Halakhah: R. Judah b. Bathyra's reason? — It has been taught: R. Judah b. Bathyra says, Of the second day of
text.3_Daf, 32_Halakhah: the Feast, Scripture Says, we-niskehem,14 [‘and their drink-offerings’] and of the sixth day,
text.3_Daf, 33_Halakhah: u-nesakeah15 [‘and its drink-offerings’] and of the seventh day, kemishpatam16 [according to their
text.3_Daf, 34_Halakhah: rule]. Note [the letters] Mem, Yod, Mem which form the word mayim [‘water’].17 Here you have the
text.3_Daf, 35_Halakhah: biblical allusion to the Libation of Water. And what makes him [R. Judah b. Bathyra] fix it on the
text.3_Daf, 36_Halakhah: second day? — Because [the first of the allusions to the Water Libation] is found in connection [with
text.3_Daf, 37_Halakhah: the order for] the second day. Hence why we should [begin] to make mention on the second day. R.
text.3_Daf, 38_Halakhah: Akiba says: On the sixth day of the Feast one [begins] to make mention, for of the sixth day
text.3_Daf, 39_Halakhah: Scripture says, And its drink-offerings.18 Scripture thus speaks of two libations,19 the Libation of
text.3_Daf, 40_Halakhah: Water and the Libation of Wine. Perhaps both Libations must be of wine? — He [R. Akiba] is of the
text.3_Daf, 41_Halakhah: same opinion as R. Judah b. Bathyra who said, There is an allusion to water.2
text.46_Daf, 0_Halakhah: One day he heard him reciting a tradition that Samuel had said: He that takes out of the sea a fish on
text.46_Daf, 1_Halakhah: the Sabbath, as soon as there is on it a dry spot as large as a sela’, he has committed a breach of the
text.46_Daf, 2_Halakhah: Sabbath laws.1 Thereupon R. Jose b. Abin asked him: Why does not the Master add, ‘and between
text.46_Daf, 3_Halakhah: the fins’? He replied : Are you not aware that R. Jose b. Abin had [already] stated this? [The former]
text.46_Daf, 4_Halakhah: retorted: I am R. Jose b. Abin. Thereupon R. Ashi enquired: Did you not frequent the discourses of
text.46_Daf, 5_Halakhah: R. Jose of Yokereth? He replied: Yes. R. Ashi then asked him: Why did you leave him, Sir, and
text.46_Daf, 6_Halakhah: come here? He replied: How could the man who showed no mercy to his son and daughter show
text.46_Daf, 8_Halakhah: What happened to his son? Once R. Jose had day-labourers [working] in the field; night set in and
text.46_Daf, 9_Halakhah: no food was brought to them and they said to his son, ‘We are hungry’. Now they were resting under
text.46_Daf, 10_Halakhah: a fig tree and he exclaimed: Fig tree, fig tree, bring forth thy fruit that my father's labourers may eat.
text.46_Daf, 11_Halakhah: It brought forth fruit and they ate. Meanwhile the father came and said to them, Do not bear a
text.46_Daf, 12_Halakhah: grievance against me; the reason for my delay is because I have been occupied up till now on an
text.46_Daf, 13_Halakhah: errand of charity. The labourers replied, May God satisfy you even as your son has satisfied us.
text.46_Daf, 14_Halakhah: Whereupon he asked: Whence? And they told him what had happened. Thereupon he said to his son:
text.46_Daf, 15_Halakhah: My son, you have troubled your Creator to cause the fig tree to bring forth its fruits before its time,
text.46_Daf, 16_Halakhah: may you too be taken hence before your time!
text.46_Daf, 17_Halakhah: What happened to his daughter? He had a beautiful daughter. One day he saw a man boring a hole
text.46_Daf, 18_Halakhah: in the fence so that he might catch a glimpse of her. He said to the man, What is [the meaning of]
text.46_Daf, 19_Halakhah: this? And the man answered: Master, if I am not worthy enough to marry her, may I not at least be
text.46_Daf, 20_Halakhah: worthy to catch a glimpse of her? Thereupon he exclaimed: My daughter, you are a source of trouble
text.46_Daf, 21_Halakhah: to mankind; return to the dust so that men may not sin because of you. He also had an ass. When it
text.46_Daf, 22_Halakhah: was hired out for the day [the people who hired it] would place, in the evening, the hire on its back
text.46_Daf, 23_Halakhah: and the ass would make its way home to its master. If, however, the money was too much or too
text.46_Daf, 24_Halakhah: little, it would not go. One day a pair of sandals were left on its back and the ass would not move
text.46_Daf, 25_Halakhah: until they were removed and only then did it proceed.
text.46_Daf, 26_Halakhah: Whenever the collectors of charity caught sight of R. Eleazar b. Birtah2 they would hide
text.46_Daf, 27_Halakhah: themselves from him, because he was in the habit of giving away to them all that he had. One day he
text.46_Daf, 28_Halakhah: was going to the market to buy a trousseau for his daughter. When the collectors of charity caught
text.46_Daf, 29_Halakhah: sight of him they hid themselves from him. He ran after them and said to them: I adjure you, [tell
text.46_Daf, 30_Halakhah: me] on what mission are you engaged? And they replied: [The marriage of] an orphaned pair. He
text.46_Daf, 31_Halakhah: said to then: I swear, they must take precedence over my daughter. And he took all that he had and
text.46_Daf, 32_Halakhah: gave to them. He was left with one zuz and with this he bought wheat which he deposited in the
text.46_Daf, 33_Halakhah: granary. When his wife returned house she asked her daughter, What did your father bring home?
text.46_Daf, 34_Halakhah: She replied, He has put in the granary all that he had bought. She thereupon went to open the door of
text.46_Daf, 35_Halakhah: the granary and she found that it was so full of wheat that the wheat protruded through the hinges of
text.46_Daf, 36_Halakhah: the door-socket and the door would not open on account of this. The daughter then went to the
text.46_Daf, 37_Halakhah: Beth-Hamidrash and said to him [her father], Come and see what your Friend has done for you.
text.46_Daf, 38_Halakhah: Whereupon he said to her, l swear,3 they shall be to you as devoted property, and you shall have no
text.46_Daf, 39_Halakhah: more right to share in them than any poor person in Israel.4
text.46_Daf, 40_Halakhah: R. Judah the Prince5 ordained a fast and he prayed but no rain fell. He thereupon exclaimed: What
text.46_Daf, 41_Halakhah: a great difference there is between, Samuel the Ramathite6 and Judah the son of Gamaliel! Woe to
text.46_Daf, 42_Halakhah: the generation that finds itself in such plight! Woe to him in whose days this has happened. He felt
text.46_Daf, 43_Halakhah: very grieved and rain fell. Once the House of the Patriarch ordained a fast and did not inform either
text.46_Daf, 44_Halakhah: R. Johanan or Resh Lakish. In the morning, however, they did notify them. Resh Lakish then said to
text.46_Daf, 45_Halakhah: R. Johanan, But we have not undertaken the fast on the previous evening.7 The latter replied: We are
text.46_Daf, 47_Halakhah: Once the House of the Patriarch ordained a fast and no rain fell. Thereupon Oshaiah, the youngest
text.46_Daf, 48_Halakhah: of the college scholars,8 expounded the verse, Then it shall be, if it be done in error by the
text.46_Daf, 49_Halakhah: congregation.9 This can be compared to a bride who lives in the house of her father. So long as her
text.46_Daf, 50_Halakhah: eyes10 are beautiful her body needs no examination; should, however, her eyes be bleared then her
text.46_Daf, 51_Halakhah: body needs examination. Thereupon the servants of the Patriarch came and put a scarf around his
text.46_Daf, 52_Halakhah: neck and tortured him. Whereupon the people of the city cried out, Leave him alone; us also he
text.46_Daf, 53_Halakhah: insults but since we see that whatever he does is for the sake of Heaven, we say nothing to him and
text.46_Daf, 54_Halakhah: we leave him alone, so you too leave him alone.
text.46_Daf, 55_Halakhah: Once Rabbi ordained a fast and no rain fell. Thereupon ‘Ilfa (some say, R. Ilfi),[stepped down
text.46_Daf, 56_Halakhah: before the ark and] recited [the prayer], ‘He causeth the wind to blow’, and the wind blew. [He
text.46_Daf, 57_Halakhah: continued], ‘He causeth the rain to fall’, and rain fell. Rabbi then asked him, What is your special
text.46_Daf, 58_Halakhah: merit? He replied: I live in a poverty-stricken remote place where wine for Kiddush and Habdalah11
text.46_Daf, 59_Halakhah: is unobtainable but I take the trouble to procure for myself wine for Kiddush and Habdalah and thus
text.46_Daf, 60_Halakhah: help also others to fulfil their duty.
text.46_Daf, 61_Halakhah: Once Rab came to a certain place and decreed a fast but no rain fell. The Reader then stepped
text.46_Daf, 62_Halakhah: down at his request before the ark and recited, ‘He causeth the wind to blow’, and the wind blew; [he
text.46_Daf, 63_Halakhah: continued], ‘He causeth the rain to fall’, and rain fell. Rab thereupon asked him, What is your special
text.46_Daf, 64_Halakhah: merit? The latter replied: I am a teacher of young children and I teach the children of the poor as
text.46_Daf, 65_Halakhah: well as those of the rich; I take no fees from any who cannot afford to pay; further, I have a fishpond
text.46_Daf, 66_Halakhah: and any boy who is reluctant [to learn] I bribe with some of the fishes from it12 and thereby appease
text.46_Daf, 67_Halakhah: him so that he becomes eager to learn.
text.46_Daf, 68_Halakhah: Once R. Nahman ordained a fast and he prayed but no rain fell. He thereupon said, ‘Take Nahman
text.46_Daf, 69_Halakhah: and throw him down from the wall to the ground’.13 He felt greatly dejected and then rain came .
text.46_Daf, 70_Halakhah: Rabbah once decreed a fast . He prayed but no rain came. Thereupon the people remarked to him:
text.46_Daf, 71_Halakhah: When Rab Judah ordained a fast rain did fall. He replied: What can l do? Is it because of studies? We
text.46_Daf, 72_Halakhah: are superior to him, because in the time of R. Judah all studies were concentrated on
